title: Reputation Matters in the Regulatory State: Re-thinking the Fundamentals of Regulatory Independence, Credibility and Accountability
descriptions:
Here is a 264-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Reputation Matters in the Regulatory State: Re-thinking the Fundamentals of Regulatory Independence, Credibility and Accountability (RICA)

The regulatory state is facing unprecedented challenges, including the devaluation of the political process and the rise of non-majoritarianism. Despite these changes, the fundamental principles of regulatory independence, credibility, and accountability remain largely unexamined. The RICA project seeks to address this gap by reconceptualizing the regulatory state and rethinking its normative and institutional design principles.

Through a two-module approach, RICA will investigate the relationship between agency insulation and credibility, and develop a new theory of accountability that accounts for the role of reputation. By drawing on insights from political science literature on reputation, RICA will challenge established wisdom and propose new theoretical frameworks that better reflect the complexities of the regulatory state.

The project's expected outcomes include a nuanced understanding of how insulation negatively affects credibility, and a comprehensive theory of accountability that recognizes the shaping power of reputation. Ultimately, RICA aims to provide policymakers and scholars with a more accurate and effective framework for evaluating and promoting regulatory independence, credibility, and accountability. By doing so, RICA will contribute to a more legitimate, effective, and accountable regulatory state.

Title: Reputation Matters in the Regulatory State: Re-thinking the Fundamentals of Regulatory Independence, Credibility and Accountability (RICA)

The RICA project challenges prevailing assumptions about the regulatory state, seeking to reconceptualize the principles of regulatory independence, credibility, and accountability. The rise of non-majoritarianism, the devaluation of political processes, and the complex relationship between accountability and autonomy necessitate a re-examination of these fundamental concepts. This project addresses these challenges through two interconnected modules. Module 1 investigates the relationship between agency insulation and credibility, hypothesizing that insulation negatively affects credibility. Module 2 develops a new theory of accountability, exploring how reputation shapes accountability behavior. By drawing on insights from political science literature on reputation, RICA will provide a nuanced understanding of the interplay between regulatory independence, credibility, and accountability. The project's innovative approach will yield new theoretical frameworks, questioning established wisdom and offering fresh perspectives on the regulatory state. Ultimately, RICA aims to enhance our understanding of the regulatory state, informing more effective institutional design principles and promoting greater accountability in regulatory governance.
